abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the partnership for polio
            eradication project for Pakistan were as follows: outcomes
            were highly satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: Substantial external
            support in terms of technical and financial resources was
            necessary to develop the system and create demand across the
            board of the value of data for effective management. By
            rewarding performance it created incentives for program
            management at the federal and provincial level for a greater
            focus on results. The key prerequisite to successful
            adoption of the buy-down mechanism or more broadly
            performance based financing is the identification of clearly
            measurable, feasible indicators that are largely within the
            control of the implementing agency and a credible monitoring
            system that provides timely information. Performance based
            financing can create incentives for developing such systems
            but more is required in terms of coordinated efforts by
            development partners to advocate for and support the process
            technically and financially.
